Analyzer.name: Helper Scope Analyzer for C/C++test Professional

Rule.desc: Do not pass incorrect values to library functions
Do not pass negative values to functions expecting non-negative arguments
Do not check for a non-negative value after passing as a non-negative argument
Do not access iterator out of range
Use valid references, pointers, and iterators to reference elements of a basic_string
Do not pass empty container iterators to std algorithms as destinations
Do not modify container while iterating over it
Always catch exceptions
Avoid signed integer overflows
Avoid use before initialization
Atomic objects shall be properly initialized before being accessed
Avoid null pointer dereferencing
Avoid buffer overflow due to defining incorrect format limits
Avoid overflow due to reading a not zero terminated string
Avoid overflow when reading from a buffer
Avoid overflow when writing to a buffer
Do not point to a wrapped object that has been freed
Avoid division by zero
Avoid accessing arrays out of bounds
A pointer pointing to an element of an array of objects shall not be passed to a smart pointer of single object type
Avoid incorrect shift operations
Use the correct byte ordering when transferring data between systems
Avoid conditions that always evaluate to the same value
Consistently check the returned value of non-void functions
Always check the returned value of non-void function
Avoid accessing collections out of bounds
Do not modify the alignment of objects by calling realloc()
The macro EOF should be compared with the unmodified return value from the Standard Library function
Properly use errno value
Properly define exit handlers
Reset strings on fgets() or fgetws() failure
Only use values for fsetpos() that are returned from fgetpos()
Avoid data loss when converting between integer types
Do not rely on an environment pointer following an operation that may invalidate it
Pointers returned by certain Standard Library functions should not be used following a subsequent call to the same or related function
The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings
Avoid calls to memory-setting functions that can be optimized out by the compiler
Properly define new handlers
Avoid throwing exceptions from functions that are declared not to throw
Never return from functions that should not return
Avoid accessing arrays and pointers out of bounds
An object shall not be assigned or copied to an overlapping object
Do not treat arrays polymorphically
Do not compare two unrelated pointers
Do not subtract two pointers that do not address elements of the same array
Do not store an already-owned pointer value in an unrelated smart pointer
Do not call putenv() with a pointer to an automatic variable as the argument
Properly define signal handlers
Do not return from a computational exception signal handler
Do not alternately input and output from a stream without an intervening flush or positioning call
Do not subsequently use the argument to std::forward
Do not rely on the value of a moved-from object
Avoid switch with unreachable branches
Properly define terminate handlers
Properly define unexpected handlers
Do not use the ungetc function on a stream with the file position indicator zero
Do not use dynamic type of an object under construction
Do not use dynamic type of an object under destruction
Ensure the size of the variable length array is in valid range
The same file shall not be opened for read and write access at the same time on different streams
Avoid writing to a stream which has been opened as read only
Avoid value change when converting between integer types
Avoid wraparounds when performing arithmetic integer operations
Ensure strings are zero terminated
Ensure the output buffer is large enough when using path manipulation functions
Always throw the created std::exception object
Suspicious setting of stream flags
Restore stream format
Avoid unused values
Guarantee that container indices are within the valid range
Properly deallocate dynamically allocated resources
Ensure deallocation functions guarantee resource freeing
Do not use resources that have been freed
Allocate sufficient memory to hold an object of a given type
Do not free resources using invalid pointers
Ensure resources are freed
Avoid cyclic shared_ptr references
Do not create variables on the stack above the defined limits
Avoid tainted data in array indexes
Prevent buffer overflows from tainted data
Avoid unsafe use of a value obtained from arithmetic operations on tainted value
Avoid buffer overflow from tainted data due to defining incorrect format limits
Avoid buffer read overflow from tainted data
Avoid buffer write overflow from tainted data
Protect against command injection
Avoid printing tainted data on the output console
Protect against environment injection
Protect against file name injection
Exclude unsanitized user input from format strings
Validate potentially tainted data before it is used in the controlling expression of a loop
Protect against SQL injection
Properly seed pseudorandom number generators
Sensitive data should be cleared before being deallocated
Avoid passing sensitive data to functions that write to log files
Validate potentially tainted data before it is used to determine the size of memory allocation
Disable resolving XML external entities (XXE) in libxerces-c
Avoid double locking
Avoid race conditions when using fork and file descriptors
Do not abandon unreleased locks
Do not acquire locks in different order
Avoid race conditions while checking for the existence of a symbolic link
Do not use blocking functions while holding a lock
Declare objects shared between POSIX threads with appropriate storage durations
Variable should be used in context of single critical section
Avoid race conditions while accessing files
Do not join or detach a thread that was previously joined or detached
The Standard Library function mtx_timedlock() shall not be invoked on a mutex that does not support timeout
Do not release a lock that has not been acquired
There shall be no data races between threads
A thread synchronization object should not be destroyed by a thread
A thread synchronization object should not be initialized by a thread
A thread should not be created by another thread
A thread-specific storage should not be created by a thread

FlowViol.msg: Data obtained from a console ("filePath[]") is injected to a file or path name
FlowViol.rule.header: Protect against file name injection

ElDesc.desc: printf("Do you want to delete the stored file path? (y/n): ");
if (scanf(" %259s", filePath) != 1) { // Limit input length to prevent overflow
fprintf(stderr, "Error: Unable to store file path.\n");

FlowViol.msg: Data obtained from a console ("filePath[]") is injected to a file or path name
FlowViol.rule.header: Protect against file name injection

ElDesc.desc: printf("No stored file path found. Please enter the license file path: ");
if (scanf(" %259s", filePath) != 1) { // Limit input length to prevent overflow
fprintf(stderr, "Error: Unable to store file path.\n");

FlowViol.msg: Data obtained from a file ("filePath[]") is injected to a file or path name
FlowViol.rule.header: Protect against file name injection

ElDesc.desc: printf("Do you want to delete the stored file path? (y/n): ");

FlowViol.rule.header: Validate potentially tainted data before it is used in the controlling expression of a loop

if (scanf(" %259s", filePath) != 1) { // Limit input length to prevent overflow
fprintf(stderr, "Error: Unable to store file path.\n");

FlowViol.msg: Data obtained from a file ("monthStr[0]") is printed on a console
FlowViol.rule.header: Avoid printing tainted data on the output console

ElDesc.desc: printf("Diaglist section found. Checking for dates...\n");
char* datePos = strstr(line, " "); // Start looking for dates after spaces
return i; // Return the zero-based index for the month
printf("Expiration date: %02d-%s-%04d, Days left: %d\n", day, monthStr, year, daysLeft);

FlowViol.msg: Data obtained from a file ("monthStr[0]") is printed on a console

FlowViol.msg: Data obtained from a file ("strcspn(...)") is used to index an array char[]
FlowViol.rule.header: Avoid tainted data in array indexes

FlowViol.rule.header: Avoid printing tainted data on the output console
